Ben did his first parkrun 3 months. First chance of running together with our 100 tops.

Matching parkrun tops

We were hosting New Years as the Elders had done Boxing day and had plenty of other entertaining to do. So we had a mixture of the normal quizzes including a personalized Cahoot quiz, Ben's music quiz, Jessica's Titles, pictures, spoons and limbo!

New Years Party

New Years Team Line-up

Today we entertained the Fars who came over for a lovely fish lunch.... well Daddy and Fars had fish (smoked halibut, smoked salmon, smoked salmon pate, eel, prawns, rollmop herrings marinated in curry and onion), we had pizza. Daddy and Katie made some bread in the morning to go with it.

Something fishy here

In the afternoon Mummy and Jessica went to hospital with Uncle Peter to visit Grandma who was looking a lot better.

Ben read, cover to cover, his Harry Potter book which he got for Christmas, 'Cursed Child'. Couldn't believe it. No iPad or PS4.

Cursed Child!

Last night Joey came over for a sleepover, and Jessica went to the Elders. Joey and Ben surprisingly weren't camped on the PS4. Deffo favourite game at the moment is Cahoot, an online quiz machine. We all joined in. They also played indoor and outdoor football and tried to get the drone going.

The Elders came over for a cup of tea and we all went to Uncle Peter's for his annual bash. Katie was still not feeling too well so had to leave after half an hour.

Jessica playing with Toby

Our annual trip to Panto saw Ethan and Auntie Susan as the newcomers this year.... as well as a surprise appearance from Joey (who does not like pantos generally) and Jessica's friend Emma.

If the shoe fits...

Great Grandma was put in an ambulance by Ma Ma and sent off to hospital. Great Grandma has had a chest infection since Christmas Day and has not been feeling too well. So as a precaution she was sent to hospital and given IV antibiotics to try and cure the problem. She is likely to spend a few days there.

We woke at the Weston's and had a leisurely breakfast before returning home and sorting through the present haul.

Later in the afternoon we went to Elders for the Barnett Boxing Day Bash where we played team games. The online quiz, Cahoot was a hit with the kids.

Kiddies

Adults

The boys

As Daddy is not the best at managing his glucose levels, Keith (the Diabetic nurse at the GPs) suggested to go on this course. Daddy was a little dismissive of it. He knows eating sugars are bad and should be equalized with an insulin intake. So he was a little sceptical on how useful the course would be.

Retrospectively speaking, the course surpassed expectations and he was really glad he went on it. So much so, Daddy really could have done with this course much earlier. What it taught him over the 3 days, was it's not sugar so much, but carbohydrates as a whole. So the porridge Daddy eats each morning requires more insulin to be taken than a doughnut for instance. During the week they calculated that for every 8 grams of carbs taken, 1 unit of Humalog is required. Also a correction dosage of 1 unit for every 2mmol. Also probably the 20 units of Lanctus was a few too many. It's now reduced to 18. The other thing learnt was carb counting. So estimating the carb content in a plate of food. This estimating process is now a lot better. Finally at the end of the course a new gluscose monitoring machine was handed out. Daddy now enters the number of carbs taken, and the machine calculates the insulin dosage. Since the course (and even during the course), Daddy's control has got a lot better. The number of really high readings has greatly reduced.

Daddy went up to the O2 with Howard on the train and met with Ma Ma in Garfunkels inside. They saw the Bryan brothers play first, then the main event of Djokovic v Thiem. In both matches the first set was tight, but the favourites in both matches ran away with it. Very enjoyable games.

Daddy and Ma Ma court side

O2 arena

Djokovic stretching for the ball

She's worked pretty hard since half term.

• Distance: 43 km
  • Climbs: 1,009 metres
  • Day 4 Route

The last day and the boys wanted to squeeze in as much as possible before the evening flight back home. Dave stopped at the villa to sort some work stuff out. The others drove to the top of Puig Major, the highest point in Majorca. On the way they stopped off at Sa Ruta Verde for yet more 'large' coffee and juices. Some clothing was also bought. They parked just before the tunnel at the top of the 8000 foot mountain. Down below was the destination, the town of Soller. It was a spec in the distance. It was pretty misty and cold so it was jackets on for the fast descent.

Before the 7200 foot Puig Major Descent

Down they went. Bob and Robin raced off, Michael hung back with Daddy and Nick attempting to get some Go Pro footage. It was a 8.5 mile trip down completed in 18 minutes. It was flat out most of the way, going full pelt before applying the brakes slightly for the sweeping bends. There were quite a few nutters road skiing back up the mountain. That was pretty hardcore. Daddy managed to hit a large stone on the way done, giving him a speed wobble. Undeterred they all raced down for the best 8.5 miles ever.

The Rockets in Soller

At Soller, Michael and Robin decided to ride back up Puig Major to the bus. They managed to clock in just under the hour which is very impressive. The others meanwhile continued through and climbed Coll de Soller. A hard climb, where Daddy yet again almost came off his bike when he was distracted rounding a tight hairpin. It was tough going. The descent on the other side was not much to write home about. The road surface was poor and length of straights short. There was a beautiful stretch of tarmac however leading into the town of Bunyola. Bob stopped off for his prized map which he had been after for the whole trip. They also got chatting to this English girl who overtook them on the Coll de Soller. She was cycling on her own, I guess no one could keep up with her. The initial climb out of Bunyola was nice, with terraced houses clinging on to the rock face. The next challenge was to attempt to get to Orient before Michael and Robin caught the three remaining boys up. In the way was the Col de Honor. A tricky little devil but had little traffic. The last hill climb of the holiday, so Daddy put all his effort into it. Another sweat on, another attempt on trying to keep Bob in Daddy's sights. 30 minutes later and the bus passed just before the summit. The road surface was pretty poor on the way down, but Daddy and Bob made it to Orient. Far beyond what they thought they could achieve today. Time was getting tight so it was villa bound in the bus.

A rather hectic clean up, lunch and departure from the villa which will be missed. It served the boys well. Will always remember Miguel for his 'uffff' comment. Not sure what it means, it is assumed it is like a huff or a sigh!

The flight home was fully booked so Dave had to stop for an extra night so he was dropped off at his hotel in the centre of Palma. With an hour or so to kill the boys took in another coffee and went souvenir shopping on the front and dipped on the beach just so they could say they touched the sea!

On the beach in Palma

The bus drop off and flight went accorrding to schedule. Daddy caught a lift with Robin, Michael and Bob and got home at 11:30pm!

Cheers boys for a fantastic trip.

• Distance: 117 km
  • Climbs: 2,573 metres
  • Day 3 Route

Waking with aching muscles from the previous day was not a good sign for the longest ride, especially as they had roughly the same climb stats as the previous day. However, after a large breakfast, the boys were almost ready to go. Daddy had another overnight puncture. This broke the breach and they looked into why he had 3 punctures within a day. Too many for a coincidence and the boys found that a previous spoke repair had been carried out without taping the wheel properly again! Thank goodness resourceful Bob had some tape with him.... and off they went - initially with a slight drizzle of rain.

On our way together

A few miles down the road, rain jackets off and a stop off at a nice little coffee / juice bar where Michael and Robin had man-sized coffees. This bar, Sa Ruta Verde, was much loved. Perhaps because it had nice drinks, merchandise and a owner who was very sociable. A challenge was set for the foxes to catch the hares up the mountain to the petrol station. Bob sneaked in first (hare), followed by Nick (hare) and Daddy (hare) then shortly after Michael (fox), Robin (fox) and Dave (hare). They stopped for 'petrol' and veered off yesterday's route down past Lluc on a short downhill stretch.

Robin and Michael enjoying big drinks for a big ride

The group split and came back together a few times as they skirted around Puig Tomir and then down some more big hills. The cars were a bit of an obstacle.... well not to Michael, he sped past most of them. Then once on the flat into and past Pollença the Rockets looked like a pro outfit. The six were drafting and making superb progress. Probably Daddy's favourite bit just because they were altogether working as a team and speeding along at a great rate. Fantastico.

An early lunch in Port de Pollença. Michael happened to drop his guts in the town centre which a couple of tourists heard. Daddy and Nick made the most of it and egged on the tourists to laugh at him and make smelly hand waving actions. All were holding their noses. I think Michael was a touch embarrassed, and so he should. :)

After many miles of easy riding, the boys were still on the way out and now the tricky Formentor peninsula had to be tackled - 12 miles of it. First a 800 foot climb to Mirador Es Colomer where there were many tourist marveling at the north coast view and an obelisk. The boys moved on attempting to tick off a mental barrier, the half way point. Many ups and downs, a tunnel and a lady wanting her picture taken by Michael were all on the route.

The tunnel on the way to Formentor

Finally, they rounded the final bend and the lighthouse was waiting and drawing the Rockets in. There were cars queueing for quite a way. Daddy smugly overtook them and reached the rest of the group. Time for looking about. Couldn't get too close to the lighthouse. The views were pretty good. Robin was bushed and I've seen worse places to kip!

Robin making the most of the views!

Rockets at Formentor 1

Rockets at Formentor 2

The actual lighthouse

They had a few group shots, before moving off on the homeward journey. Again good initial pace was made and the journey off the peninsula seemed much quicker than the one to the lighthouse. They hugged the coast down Port de Pollença again turning right and much relief away from the traffic and other cyclists. In fact it was nice to be alone again. Daddy and Nick followed the route back whilst the others took a slightly longer route - they got lost! Daddy by now with only 10 miles to go was flagging seriously and had to stop a number of occasions. Nick was great support. Finally everyone met at the local bar, Bar Sa Tafona in Biniamar for a well earned beer.

Well deserved beer in Biniamar

The last evening and the decision was made to go out to eat. Biniamar had nothing to offer, so whilst we were getting ready Mr King was tasked on finding a place to eat. They crammed in the bus and headed for the next town of Llosseta. Nick on navigation took them down some very narrow streets and credit to E'ster who drove superbly. The passengers just shut their eyes and prayed. They dumped the van in the town square (a bit unorthodox) and set on foot. Nick not inspiring confidence on knowing where he was going. We almost completed a lap, but stumbled across the targeted, Celler Can Carrossa Restaurante. Not many in, and looked a little too fine for the rabble of men. However, we set forward and went for the set menu. Course after course came out. I think Nick must have sweated a bit as the diners were getting increasingly concerned at the final bill. Siz courses of fine dining later, the bill came out at just 35 euros each. A bargain considering the quality. They had puffer fish, lamb, sorbet, and many other dishes. Nick got a pat on the back in the end. An end to great day. Packed a lot in.

• Distance: 79 km
  • Climbs: 3,108 metres
  • Day 2 Route

The first big day and the iconic Sa Calobra with it's twisting, switch back roads. To reach it - there were a couple of climbs to be tackled. Cutting through Biniamar to Selva then a lovely stretch of road to the favourite Caimari.

Rockets on the road

Lovely straight road between Selva and Caimari

The first major climb up the Coll de sa Batalla (381m) was a workout and a sign for things to come over the next 3 days! Robin and Michael shot off as they were so much quicker than the remaining four. That was pretty much the last time they were seen! The rocky limestone mountains created a complex and striking landscape, dotted with fig and olive trees that cling to the mountain side. It’s no wonder the mountain range has been awarded UNESCO World Heritage status. The four reached the peak and the petrol station landmark at the top. A hub for all cyclist, road and off road. Don't think any cars actually filled up with petrol. Some of the views on the ascent were breath taking. Also the first experience of the switch backs. When you see switch back roads you know you've hit the serious stuff.

On the way up to the top of Coll de sa Batalla

Two hours in and only 16 miles covered, but 1500m climbed. The four reach the top of Sa Calobra.... and what a view. All those winding roads. They stayed at the top for photos and to see the coaches struggle around the bends. Then the decent! Bob and Dave raced down, whilst Daddy and Nick stopped here and there for a few photos. Wow what a decent - speeds close to 40mph. Near the bottom of the mountain Daddy got a puncture, luckily it wasn't when he was going fast - the first ever on a road bike. As they were fixing it, Michael and Robin went past on the way back up Sa Calobra. They were doing a huge 70 mile lap!

Top of Sa Calobra

Daddy and Nick laughing at Sa Calobra

Daddy and Nick searched for Bob and Dave, but couldn't find them. They went all the way down to the beach part via the caves at Port de Sa Calobra. A couple of plush looking yachts were anchored in the bay. Daddy tripped over a rock making him bleed and causing a deep intake of air from a passing tourist. Kingster is still laughing now I think.

Yachts in Port De Sa Calobra

Stopping for lunch

After a spot of lunch and a chat with some fellow cyclists Daddy and Nick had the unenviable climb back up the 722m mountain in the midday sun and for Daddy on a half inflated back tyre. It was the toughest bit of cycling - and they had to stop twice for a rest. 1:20 hours later and they reached the top - all energy and enthusiasm gone. It was now all about getting back. Puncture number two arrived just after the petrol station. Spooky.

Like a gorge in the middle of the road on the way up

A quick stop on the way up for recovery!

Poodling back down Coll de sa Batalla Daddy and Nick decided to roll into Inca and attempt to get some more cash out. It was nice seeing Inca from a cyclists perspective. The return journey home went a bit off road, but the boys finished the toughest 49 mile ride ever.

Daddy was the first, last and only one to get into the swimming pool to do a few lengths. Again Bob and Dave surpassed themselves and cooked up a lovely BBQ and all six sat outside and munched through some much needed fuel for tomorrow. Later they watched some of the Go Pro footage from E'sters bike.

Alfresco dining

• Distance: 47 km
  • Climbs: 232 metres
  • Day 1 Route

Daddy, Uncle Michael, Nick, Bob, Robin and Dave all decided to go on a cycling holiday together in Majorca. It was an early flight, meaning Daddy left home at 2:00am to meet first with Bob. However, first issue. As Daddy had to carry quite a bit on his motorbike he clipped his cycle helmet to the bag, meaning it was flapping around at 80mph down the A331. Then fling..... the helmet was no longer attached. Daddy hadn't realized this until reaching Bob's house. So a speedy exit back onto the A331, followed by a crawl in the dark to find the missing helmet, hoping no other vehicle had damaged it. Fortunately, it was lying at the side of the road in North Camp without damage! Not a great start.

Dave met up and drove to Gatwick where all the crew met together. Only Daddy got stopped at security (for no reason!) and then off and away on the 5:40am flight to Palma.

Having arrived in warmer climes, they picked up the hire car and shot off to the villa (Cami Vell) in Biniamar, via the supermarket and bank in Inca. Daddy was having trouble getting enough cash out of the ATM to pay for the villa. Fortunately they got around the problem, and after an hour's worth of showing the villa off, Miguel left the tried, but still eager cyclists to their own devices. Unfortunately when the bikes turned up Dave's was the wrong size. Michael also wanted to spend a bit of time adjusting his bike, so only Daddy, Robin, Nick and Bob went cycling and headed 20 miles eastwards towards Port d'Alcúdia. Nick and Bob almost had a coming together when a car turned in on then.... they attempted to see the sea, but realized they were looking at Es Llac Gran, a lake!

Es Llac Gran

They crossed the road, saw some ladies play beach volleyball and moved on quickly, deciding to head north and meet up with the other two in Port de Pollença! Cycling was like a dream. Perfect weather conditions, the roads on the whole were smooth and a pleasure to ride on. One stretch however along the bay, Badia de Pollença, had a narrow, bumpy, two way cycle path, which would be very dangerous if not fully concentrating. Pedestrians and runners also shared this highway. A couple of incidents!

The four reached Port de Pollença and found Tolos Bar and supped on a couple of pints of strong lager.... the strength of which is still not resolved today! It blew Bob's socks off anyway. Even Michael squeezed in a pint (and was last to finish still).

Tolos Bar

After another trip to the supermarket the boys returned to the villa where Dave cooked up a massive, scrummy Spag Bol. A long day, considering it started at 1:30am.

title.value: Majorca Biking Day 1 - Port d'Alcúdia, Port de Pollença

info.content:
Daddy roasted a pork on the BBQ for lunch which we shared with Uncle Steven, Joyce, Eva and Molly, plus Summer. Later in the afternoon we went down the park to play on the swings and have a game of football.

Mummy with Molly

In the morning Ben played football and narrowly lost 3-2. Daddy was linesman.

We went to St Peters church to look around the scarecrows.

Spot the scarecrows

We sneaked into Camberley so Jessica could do some girly shopping.

The eldery

Katie met with Summer and spent the day at Chessington World of Adventures. Summer came back and stayed over.

title.value: Ben Football, Church Scarecrow, Katie to Chessington World of Adventures, Summer Sleepover

info.content:
In the morning we went to church whilst Daddy went to London and set himself a challenge of cycling around the grounds of: Brentford, QPR, Fulham, Chelsea, Arsenal and Wembley. He found it a bit of a struggle, but completed it nonetheless. Football Grounds Route

After lunch, we started the long awaited treasure hunt that Farfar had prepared. We started at home and cycled into the rec, then Henley Drive, the Hatches, then along the path on the Blackwater River all the way to North Camp. There were 15 clues to get to this stage. They were pitched just at the right level of difficulty. Ben had the classic impatient, give it me attitude and fell into the trap of, if not finding the answer straight away then give up.... then when he read half the clue, would rush off! This would cost us dearly later on!

After over 2 hours we eventually made it to the half way stop at the Mytchett Canal Centre where we stopped for refreshments with the Fars. Ice Creams and drinks all round. Part 2 of the treasure hunt saw us explore into the woods behind the café. This proved more challenging and more popular for some reason. We eventually ended up at bottom of Deepcut, passing some horses along the way. Here we trusted Ben a bit too much. 'After Lakeland House' take the next right, go along the road for a bit and look for a sign naming the woods'. Well Ben thought he saw the house at the corner with the mini roundabout so we turned up Bellew Road. We looked left, no evidence of the sign. We went up the big hill, some had to walk. Still nothing. We basically went the length of Bellew Road into Deepcut. We doubled back again and went to the junction with Lake Road. Daddy Re-read the clue and questioned the Lakeland House part of the clue and wanted to see for himself this house. It was not where Ben had said it was. In fact we shouldn't have gone down Bellew Road at all. Lakeland House was further towards Frimley Green. We should have turned down St Catherines Road. To atone for his earlier mistake Ben went rushing off to look for the sign. Yep you guessed it. He rushed right past it and ended up near to the Fars house. Daddy found the sign a kilometre back! We must have lost half an hour due to Ben's antics. We all had a laugh about it! We ended the 28 clues back at our house and dealt out the final treasure which proved fruitful for us children. Treasure Hunt Route

title.value: 6 Football Grounds Bike Tour, Farfar's Bike Treasure Hunt

info.content:
Mummy and Daddy went to get their flu jab first thing. Daddy went to parkrun and ran very slowly and joined Ben at football - RouteParkrun. This time he played a mixture of centre midfield and striker. They lost 9-0!

In the afternoon, Daddy and Jessica spent the afternoon with farmor round her house at first, then they went into Frimley Road to get some eel, monkfish and herring from the fish shop!

Later they joined Mummy, Katie and Ben down at the church fair. Mummy ran the tattoo stall whilst Ben took charge of the Beat The Goalie stall. He was complimented on how good he was with all the younger children. He was very good with them.

In the afternoon the girls watched Finding Nemo.

So new school year means a change in clubs.

    Katie:
  • Youth club
  • Trampolining (Farnborough - Tuesdays's)
  • Given up Guides
    Jessica:
  • Brownies
  • Trampolining (Farnborough - Tuesdays's)
  • Given up gymnastics from last term
    Ben:
  • Football (Thursday's and Saturday's)
  • Given up Scouts and parkrun partially from last term

We went to church whilst Daddy decided to bike down to Hayling Island. The weather was just perfect for the journey. Route

Top of hill past South Harting

The family picnic was well attended. We played in the sea and had a mass game of volleyball followed by ice creams.

Even Daddy swum in the sea!

Family Volleyball

Sea selfie

First up Daddy managed to do a parkrun, then hurried off to Heatherside where Ben was playing football. This week Ben was captain and played pretty much the whole match at right back. First time in defence. He didn't enjoy it so much. They only lost 3-1. Quite an even game.

Ben captain leading the handshakes

In the late afternoon Katie went to a birthday party around the corner where they did a treasure hunt around the village and played on the trampoline, in the dark!

title.value: Parkrun, Ben Football, Katie at Party

info.content: A Tomlinscote inset day. Katie went to Thorpe Park with her friends, without parents. Ben played with Oli, Kieron and Yuv on Star Wars Battlefront and went in to Camberley for a Frenchies!

Last night Katie and Ben decided to surprise Jessica by sneaking her out of bed and have a secret sleepover style night downstairs with sweets and a film. Very sweet of Jessica's siblings.

Present opening was performed of course in bed. The cards came first. Jessica had amassed £130 in cash and £20 in vouchers.... plus she got some clothes, a special world setup in Minecraft and a trampoline. She was very pleased.

Mummy let us off church so we could play. After lunch, we went into Camberley first for a swim in a relatively quiet pool. We had half the pool to ourselves, so it was fun to have the freedom to muck about.

After, we ventured into Camberley and went in to Frenchies, now owned by Yuvraj's parents. We had ice cream, pancakes and smoothies. We did some girly shopping, whilst the boys rode back home.

Frenchies

Daddy and Ben were not off to parkrun this week. A long, long time since that last happened. Instead Ben has been training with Mytchett Athletic U12's for the past 2 weeks and has really enjoyed it especially a few of his mates also play (Kieron, Freddie, Oliver).

Team talk

Mytchett Falcons U12 Lineup

First game is at home, played in the park next to the Lion Brewery, Ash against Fleet Mustangs. It's 9 a-side on a 1/2 pitch, 30 minutes each way, rolling subs. We had 11 players, including one girl, Lucy. Ben has and was very excited to be playing, although gutted to miss parkrun. He was larking about with his mates for most of the warm-up. Daddy was on the strictest of instructions not to 'give advice' and just let Ben get on with it! Ben started centre midfield and surprised Daddy on how well he did. He got involved. He looked to get the ball, rather than wait to come to him, he 'skilled' people, he passed, he shielded all very good. At this age strength is a bit of a problem in terms of kicking the ball hard and getting shrugged off the ball. Mytchett were outclassed really. There was the rare attack from us. On one occasion, Ben bullied his way throw and the goalkeeper took him out. Penalty! Ben steps up and........ keeper saves it. Bad luck Ben. Ben got 'studded' at the end of the first half which made him cry. He got up though and got on with it. Eventually we were on the end of a 7-0 defeat but the team enjoyed themselves, which is the most important thing. Ben got man of the match. Daddy was linesman.

Ben won man of the match

Meanwhile, Jessica's 9th birthday party was underway back at home. After inspiration from the Bake Off, Jessica wanted a Bake Off party. When we looked around for someone to run they want over £150! Mummy thought we could do it ourselves so brought mixing bowls, wooden spoons and the ingredients to make Chocolate Hand Prints, Flowerpots, Sandcastle, Tea set fairy cakes, icing ice cream cones. Ma Ma aka Mary Berry judged the cakes and Amy Huggett came first!

Baking time

The entertained contestants

The judging

Amy Huggetts (winner) and Jess

title.value: Jessica's 9th birthday party, Ben's first Mytchett Falcons U12s match

info.content:
Daddy and the Frimley Flyers ran event number 5 of 7. No one had done any training, so for many it was a case of getting around rather than looking at smashing pb's. Daddy targeted 2:06 and came in at 2:04. So he was pleased, although it's well down and what he should be doing!

Route

Daddy enjoyed a nice drink with the boys in the pub afterwards and was very lazy for the rest of the day!

Team lineup for the day

In the morning Daddy and Ben did parkrun at Frimley Lodge, then went on to join the others at Ravenscote school for the final production of our plays.

In the evening the Fars came over to babysit us. They took us down to the sweet shop. Naughty naughty. Meanwhile one of Mummy's friends from church had a Hawaiian themed 50th birthday party at the Lion Brewary pub in Ash. Mummy had a few cocktails and beers and suffered a bit later on.

Hawaiian night out

Mummy enjoying herself!

16 years of marriage! Blimey. Anyway gifts were exchanged. Mummy got a lovey dress and a hoody, whilst Daddy got a wearable tea towel!

Mummy and Daddy before going out

In the evening they celebrated in the Italian Steakhouse just under Windsor Castle. They both enjoyed their Italian meal.

Meanwhile us kiddies went to the Elders for some fun and games and stayed the night.

title.value: Daddy and Mummy's 16th Wedding Aniversary, Sleepover at Elders

info.content:
This week we went to church club. Mummy and Katie were both helpers. We did various activities and although we protested most days once we were there we enjoyed ourselves.

Church club play

Walking past a horsey

Walking past Hascombe Church

Katie and Ben sharing a laugh

Group shot at the top of the hill

Another group shot

Overlooking the countryside towards Dunsfold

A lot of tree climbing

Route
Katie slept over at Summer's on Saturday and Sunday night. They went down to Brighton and got a pass to go on the amusement rides on the pier.

Ben and James pleased to see each other

Proud dad and Ben

We actually did some running

Joey and Ellie ran too

100 up

Cake time

A card from James

The parkrun family

Big boys

Down the café afterwards for a nice drink and food

Route

Tonight Jessica joined Katie and slept over at the Teale's. Meanwhile at our house we had Toby, Lily, Joey and Auntie Ellie over for a sleepover. Daddy had gone to see David Brent at the cinema and gave it 7 out of 10.

Katie went along with Nina, Natasha and Grace to Thorpe Park as part of Natasha's birthday party. Ben also chipped along paying it for himself from his birthday money. He was desperate to get on to Stealth. However, it has been shut due to works being carried out on it, which was a shame. However, they did have a good time. A bit worrying to hear what Nina was going to get up to.

Farfar is 70 today! and we celebrated by taking SS Molly May for a second taster along the Thames. This time westwards. Of course there were excuses for the 35 minute late arrival, but we all clambered aboard. After an explore of the boat we settled down and played a game of Coppit. Our favourite. We went through a few locks which was fun. One of them we ended up sideways which was funny and embarrassing at the same time. I'm saying nothing, but Farfar was at the tiller and engine throttle at the time! We made it to the Bells Of Ouzeley on the edge of Old Windsor for lunch. A nice burger settled the stomach.

Jessica relaxing on the boat roof

We then turned around at this point. We all had a go at taking control of the boat, except Katie who was to nervous. When Daddy took the helm he purposely went close to the bank where there were overhanging trees, and you've guessed it. We all ducked as the branches strapped across the top of the boat and the sunbathes on top! We stopped off at Runnymede Pleasure grounds where we played on the swings and a chance to present Farfar with his birthday cake and sing happy birthday.

We then cruised quickly back to Laleham, our exit point as we were running late on the schedule. As Farfar undocked again he almost hit the moored boat. Worse still he did this because he lost concentrating on chatting to the victims on the target vessel! Oh Farfar. We had a lovely day. Happy birthday Farfar.

The Far sailing off into the sunset

Even after a long bike ride, Daddy needed to get his parkrun in, so went to Blandford parkrun and ran a respectable 27 minutes.

Us children went for a swim in the outdoor heated pool and had a mini table tennis tournament. Winner stays on. Ma Ma ended up beating Pop Pop, Ellie, Katie, Ben and Joey.

In the afternoon some of us went to try and catch the air show. However, we didn't know until it was too late that it had been cancelled due to the high winds. Ben, Pete, Ma Ma, Mummy and Daddy went to first Tyneham . A village taken over by the army in the war, and never returned. So everything was left as was in 1943. It was interesting to see the restoration process. We then later went over to Kimmeridge Bay where the wind was really gusting. The aim of the game was fossil hunting. It was strange to see the cliff being eroded before us, not by the sea, but by the wind. The cliffs seemed to made of shale.

Kimmeridge Bay

The evening came, uncle Michael had biked down and we all went out for a meal in Wimborne.

title.value: Wareham Camping - Blanford parkrun, Tyneham, Kimmeridge Bay

info.content:
The weather has been great all week, today of all days Daddy decided to come and join us, but he was cycling down. He had to contest a headwind and rain for the most part of the journey.

He left at 8am and got to Fleet Station where he met with Bob and they merrily set off the back roads down to Winchester. The weather was drawing in. Moral suffered a bit as they headed for Romsey and luchtime. Half way, Bob decided to venture back on the train. Sensible lad. The next step of the journey through the New Forest saw the worst of headwinds and rain. Daddy didn't mind so much although it was a challenge at navigating the map and using the mobile phone with rain drops all over. Daddy reached Ringwood, headed south towards Hurn, then across to Wimbourne and Wareham. A total of 95 miles. Daddy had a welcoming committee at the gates which was ever so nice.

Route

title.value: Daddy bikes down to Wareham Forest

info.content:
We had less than 24 hours at home before venturing off again. This time the Weston camping holiday down in Wareham Forest.

Tents up

Meanwhile Daddy stayed home as was going to be working part of the week. In the evening he played croquet against Farfar and done better than previous years.

Farfar taking his shot in croquet match

The last day. Boo Hoo. Daddy went off to run in the Poole parkrun and did rather well. Finally he was pleased with a run. We packed up left some bits for Charlotte and Loz for when they return from honeymoon. We headed to the New Forest where we went for a Pokémon Hunt aka, a walk from the walk book. It took absolutely forever to find the start point. We went round and round in circles. Still we had a picnic and took the bikes. Unfortunately mummy also had the map and took us in the wrong direction. Us children were not too happy we just wanted to get home. Eventually we did make it home to end our lovely holiday.

Picnic time again

Godshill Cycle

title.value: Bournemouth Holiday - Poole parkrun, Walk 82: Godshill Walk

info.content:
We had a relatively late start this morning as we headed over to Tower Park. Splashdown is a swimming complex with lots of flumes. When we went to pay the assistant asked for £85!! Daddy almost fell over on how expensive this swimming outing was going to be. However, we wanted to go in, so Daddy had to take the hit! We attempted to go on every single flume. There were even some outdoor parts which made it a little different. Daddy thought it was good, but not £85 good. After we went to Branksome and played in a park and had our picnic before we returned home. Later in the afternoon we headed out to Bournemouth beach and did the usual swim and play.

Picnic in the park at Branksome

title.value: Bournemouth Holiday - Splashdown, Branksome and Bournemouth Beach

info.content:
Along to Portland we went. We got a little lost and ended up at the prison at the top of the hill. Eventually much to the disgust of the children we reached Verne High Angle Battery. We explored the tunnels which were very dark and had a picnic on top of the hill. We could see for miles. We could see Chesil Beach stretching into the distance.

Mummy and Daddy on the top of Portland

Tunnels in Verne Battery

We returned to Weymouth and looked around the shops for a little bit then headed to the beach where we did a bit of swimming. Then came as a surprise for mummy as part of her 40th birthday present Daddy promised her a ride on a speedboat, so he bought tickets and we all went at high speed along the water. It was great fun. We had fantastic time.

Just before our swim

Rib ride around Weymouth

Time marched on so we headed towards Poole for our special meal. It was a celebration for all the hard work us children have performed during the school year. After we headed to the quay where we saw the weekly firework display.

Special meal out in Poole. Well done children for a good school year.

Poole Fireworks. Watched from the quay

title.value: Bournemouth Holiday - Verne Batery, Weymouth, Poole Fireworks

info.content:
We started early and headed for Ellington Lakes where we had booked a 9:30 banana boat ride. We were a little nervous as we hadn't done this before. Again Ben took this competitively as we were asked if we minded been thrown from the banana! Mummy and Daddy were out shouted! We went quite quickly along the water and the driver chucked us of and we hit the water hard. The driver proceeded to try to chuck us off again. The three eldest fell off whilst the two youngest gleefully stayed on. 15 minutes were up and time for the final throw off. Guess who stayed on? Ben managed to cling on and delightfully told the rest of us how clever he was.

Wet suited up (inside out Daddy) before our banana boat ride

We took a long drive to Lymington where we grabbed a pasty and a crabbing kit and sat on the harbour wall attempting to catch crabs whilst eating our lunch. Daddy was curious to see the lido so we glanced at it as we drove past. Guess what, yes another inflatable floating on the water. So we parked up, hired wetsuits and us kiddies went in the water and challenged ourselves to go round all the inflatables whilst Mummy and Daddy sat on the side watching.

Just got pasties in Lyminton

What is Mummy doing? Being sick?

Ben tackling the assault course

Jessica enjoying herself

Reaching the end of the course together

Day 4 did not start off too well. Daddy had not brought enough insulin with him so he had to go back to real home to get another pen. Later in the morning we headed north up to Wimborne Minster where we collected some blueberries at a pick your own place. They were scrumptious. Jessica almost got daddy into trouble when she told him loudly not to keep eating the blueberries as they were being picked.

We then moved onto the lakes where we went to the Aqua Park. This is an assault course floated in the middle of a lake. We got our wetsuits and spent the next hour bouncing around on the inflatables. We had a great time. The weather was really nice and we stayed a little longer to play in the water. After, we headed into Fordingbridge where we grabbed some treats and had a quick walk around the village.

Jessica picking blueberries for Daddy to eat!

Aqua Park behind

title.value: Bournemouth Holiday - Blueberry picking, Aqua Park, Fordingbridge

info.content:
Day 3 of our holiday and we decided to use the bikes and make the University run back into Bournemouth the way Daddy used to. We biked to Westcliff, down to the pier. At the pier we did some activities including the death slide and children's caving. This was great fun. Finally four of us went down the zip slide from the end of the pier down to the beach. Katie and Ben were first to go and zipped straight down. Next was daddy and Jessica. Jessica was very hesitant and Daddy thought she wasn't going to slide down. However, after a bit of encouragement she surprised us all and flew down the zip wire. We played a bit on the beach then had a glance around the shops for a couple of hours returning back to the beach and eventually we cycled home and watched more Olympics.

illegally biking along Bournemouth promenade

The death slide. Ben went from the top

The lovlies on Bournemouth pier

We drove all the way to Lulworth Cove where we started a nice of walk to Durdle Door. There was a lot of moaning from the children. However, once we got down to the beach we played and climbed the cliffs and explored some of the caves before turning around and heading back into Lulworth Cove. It was quite busy with tourists. We had our picnic around the busy cove watching the waves trickle in. We attempted to skim stones without too much success.

Climbing with Lulworth Cove in the distance

Durdle Door

Cliff playground

Run away

We then drove through the back roads to Swanage where we parked up headed to the beach and played in the sea. Daddy was persuaded to hire a pedalo so he could drag us all around the bay. Mummy stood on the beach, eagle eyed watching us. We spent a couple of hours on the beach then headed towards the fish and chip shop and had our chips on the harbour wall. We played in the arcades and somehow came out on with a profit. Jessica did very well on the 2p sliding machines. Another evening of Olympic action.

Pedloing at Swanage

Eating chips in Swanage Bay

title.value: Bournemouth Holiday - Lulworth Cove, Durdle Door, Swanage

info.content:
This year we have capitalised on Charlotte and Loz being on honeymoon by stealing their house for a week and basing our holiday around the Bournemouth area. However, before reaching Bournemouth we had to satisfy daddy's needs and go to parkrun Southampton where he did two laps around the park. We eventually made it to Charlotte's house and dumped our stuff before heading out to Southbourne Beach. The weather was really nice and we decided to spend the Far's holiday money on a rubber dinghy. However, the sea was very choppy so it was hard to use it properly. We spent an hour or two on the beach playing in the water and building sandcastles, before returning back home and having a nice barbecue. Most of the evenings during the holiday have been spent on watching the 2016 Rio Olympics.

Choppy sea

Need to bury his head in the sand!

We woke up early as usual for Ben's birthday. We congregated in Mummy and Daddy's bedroom where Ben started opening his cards first then his presents. He was super excited about the PS4 that he got. He also received lots and lots of money so he could spend it on his PS4.

We had to leave early as we were going up to the Olympic swimming pool in London. There we had booked for an hour and a half session on the inflatable assault course. It was very strictly run which was good as it allows us to all have some proper goes along the tricky apparatus. Of course Ben was competitive and tried to beat everybody else. Mummy on the other hand struggled to complete the course without falling in.

Ben in the Olympic Swimming Pool complex. Assault course behind

After swimming we mooched around the Olympic park playing in the water fountains, admiring West Ham's new council pitch and playing in the playground.

Impressive Aquatics Centre

Mummy and Daddy outside the ArcelorMittal Orbit

We drove through the centre of London on the way home to see some sights. Pizza for tea. Happy birthday Big Boys.

In the morning it was clear up time. There was a lot to do down at the village hall. Eventually finished at midday, we then all went over to the Waller's household in Swanley where Sienna was having her 3rd birthday. It was nice to spend time over with Pop Pop's side of the family. We had a massive BBQ and played some party games where there was some cash prizes on offer. That perked up the interest. We had a very nice afternoon.

Dancing in the Waller's Front Garden

We watched Charlotte and Loz open their wedding presents. They a massed over £3000 in total. We made it home in the early evening. An exhausting weekend.

Opening wedding presents

Daddy looking cool

In the morning Daddy went to Frimley Lodge parkrun, whilst the rest of us woke early to the tones of 'We're going to the chapel' in Ma Ma and Pop Pop's house. All the bridesmaids stayed over as well as Ellie and Lily. Make up, hair and nails all done in the morning. Meanwhile Loz was staying at the local Premier Inn. The girls house was remarkably calm, I mean Auntie Charlotte didn't get out of her dressing gown until gone 11am! The congregation started arriving at the Ship Inn pub at the bottom of the road in Southfleet an hour or so before kick-off. The weather was just about OK, warm, but there was a slight threat of rain - that thankfully never materialized.

Flower Girls and Katie outside church

Ben and Elders getting a swift pint in before proceedings

Joey, Fraser and Ben

St. Nicholas church filled up, Loz's side of the family on the right as you walk in, and our side on the left. It appeared to be equal number from both sides of the family. I don't think there were any absentees. Nice to think that all three sisters are married in the same church. The vicar proceeded with a lengthy notices section. Loz looked really nervous. The gum was being chewed at an excessive rate! Deep breathes. Then Charlotte arrived with Pop Pop on her arm preceded by Holly, Lily and Jessica, the flower girls. It was all getting quite emotional. Katie, Stacey, Marina and Sues were the bridesmaids following. All the girls looked beautiful all with big smiles. The vicar kept the service nice and light - Daddy even listened to most of it! Loz and Charlotte laughed, almost cried, but enjoyed the service. After an hour, we went outside for photos. The new Mr and Mrs Maisey were whisked away in the wedding car, all of 200 metres to the village hall where the wedding breakfast and reception was to be held.

Daddy having a chat with the Barnett's

The bride with Lils and Katie

The sisters

The beautiful couple

With the girls

Us lot

After some swift drinks, a game of football and some photos we went inside for the wedding breakfast. A bit different, a BBQ. Brilliant. 4pm - Food was delicious and much needed. Us kiddies had our own marquee where we sat and ate. Then came the speeches. We eagerly awaited Pop Pop's speech. See how long he would last before having to hand over to Ma Ma. I think it was a new record. One and a half lines! Ma Ma then delivered. Loz made his address before handing over to his two best men who were fantastic. Great speeches guys.

The dodgems and bouncy slide opened and the kids were set free for mayhem. We saw some sterling driving performances from some of the 'older' kids, namely Bradley and Farmor. There were some sough necks and backs in the morning after some heavy impacts. Some spectacular sliding on the inflatable also. Daddy managed a forward somersault off the top. The first dance was performed in front of the live band. Later the photo booth turned up where we had some fun dressing up in front of the camera. Daddy and Uncle Michael sampled some of the cocktails on offer. There was a lot going on. It was hard to get around to actually chatting and socialize. Too much fun to be had.

Proceedings ended at about 11:30pm. All of us shattered, but had a great day. Many congratulations Mr and Mrs Maisey!!

Mummy and Daddy

Dodgems

Daddy somersault

Careful lady drivers

Katie has been looking forward to this day in a very long time. She loves getting stuff and having party games with the family... I think to recreate Christmas in some respects! Anyway it was stupid o'clock on a Sunday morning and Katie began opening cards then presents. She amassed loads. Over £200 in cash and vouchers as well as the eagerly awaited iPhone 6 SE and case and tripod! She also got lots of smellies and a shopping trip.

We had the family over for a BBQ and games. It was boys versus girls.

Getting the iPhone 6

Family BBQ

Cake time

The weather continued to be good which made the trip down to the Quays very worth while. Alice had a donutting and wakeboard party. In Katie's words - 'That was the best party ever, I want that next year'. At first Katie was apprehensive about getting into the water as the fish might eat her! However, after a bit she was in the water no problem. She loved the donutting and wake boarding.

Meanwhile Daddy and Ben park runned. Daddy possibly having his worst performance ever. Over 27 minutes! The recent Abs challenge obviously not making a positive effect. Ben now on 99 runs. However, due to weddings, no park Frimley Lodge parkrun and holidays, we are not sure when the magic 100 is going to happen.

Later in the afternoon Natasha came over to stay and we all went out to Camberley to get some last minute presents for Katie's party.

Katie Wake Boarding

title.value: Alice's Quays Birthday Party, Natasha sleepover

info.content:
Katie invited 10 friends over to the Spectrum, Guildford for a swimming party plus food afterwards in the Wimpey bar! Cosmic. She of course had a great time. Thanks to Paula who helped out massively in providing taxi cover!

Spectrum party go-ers

title.value: Katie's 13th Birthday Party - Spectrum with Friends

info.content:
The perennial problem of setting a child's birthday party date when their birthday is in August. All the kiddies become unavailable because of the holidays. So today was set after a previous date failed to stick. This year it was in no doubt, a football party on the local 3G pitches. 13 players, already divided in two teams by Ben. The egos, one up-man-ship, showing off was rife, systematic of a bunch of 11 year olds who also finish school tomorrow. In some respects nice to see they were all at their peak! Anyway Daddy was referee in this 20 minutes a half match which ended 4-3 to Ben's team. The temperatures were high but this did not bother anymore. A final penalty competition ensued before retiring to the shade and a Domino's pizza for all. Everyone seemed to have a great time.

11 Year Old Footballers

Pizzas

Within an hour of the party finishing, we whipped Ben over to the school for the final year play. One was performed earlier in the day to the rest of the school.... Jessica cried because she is going to miss Ben being there. She said 'When I forgot my lunch the other day, Ben gave me his food'. Bless. Ben played a chavie Dad who got aggressive with the teacher. He of course played the part very well, even gaining a comment from the headmistress.

Ben starring as a chavie dad

title.value: Ben's 11th Birthday Party, Ben's school play

info.content:
Kindly James and Duncan took Ben around the Star Wars Exhibition at London Excel. Ben had a great time liking the Rogue One exhibition and listening to the panel answer interview questions.Seeing Fin and the new Hans Solo. There were lots of people signing and selling autographs and there were loads of Star Wars enthusiasts running their own stalls. Ben loved seeing all the dressed characters like Hawaian Chewbacka and the new Death Troopers. wandering around. He was there from 9am to 5:30pm but could have stayed longer.

Star Wars Celebration

Ben captured by Snow Troopers

Ben and his Stormtrooper buddy

Ben and Dunc admiring the Bobafet figure

Ben and a Jawa

Ben and the robots

AT AT chasing you boys

Many thanks James and Duncan.

Meanwhile Daddy went outdoor karting at Thruxton with Loz and Michael. It was a bit of a pre-wedding get together. There were three races, each qualifying for the next race. Daddy qualified 4th, then 3rd and finished the final in second out of about 15 racers. Daddy had a lot of tussles with Michael on the track which was fun. Loz did really well finishing 6th in the final. We were all quite evenly paced. After we skidded into the pub, Pop Pop made his way from Clacton to join us where we had a nice mixed grill meal!

Stylish lads karting

Second out of 15

title.value: Ben Star Wars Exhibition, Daddy Karting

info.content:
Last night Ben had a sleepover at Freddies and did not go to sleep, so when he arrived home, mid morning he was totally knackered and slept for most of the day!

Auntie Charlotte stayed over last night after the girls spa experience. She was dragged to parkrun with Daddy and posted a respectable 27:46 time! Just think Daddy's first parkrun was shared with Charlotte... Daddy is now on 168. After Auntie Charlotte took Jessica down to Bournemouth for an overnight stay at her house. First they did ran some errands, then painted small bits of wood which the napkins are going in for the wedding in two weeks time. They then went to the DVD shop and got Pitch Perfect Sing Along and Aquamarine. It wouldn't work on Charlotte's DVD player though, so Jessica took them home. Both Lenny and Loz's Dad, John kept us company. Jessica slept with Auntie Charlotte in the big bed.

On the Sunday, they went to church and then walked Lenny by the Sloppy Lake (whatever that is). Finally they went to the Beach. Jessica paddled in the sea and got ice cream! Thank you very much Auntie Charlotte, a lovely 24 hours.

title.value: Auntie Char Char overnighter for Jessica, Ben sleepover at Freddies

info.content: Mummy went to the Nirvana Spa with Ellie, Charlotte and Ma Ma for a relaxing evening.

Jessica got her school report back today and we could not be happier. It would appear she is just above average generally with no concerns, just neatness in her writing. Top marks for effort on every subject. She got on well with her teacher, Mrs Baker, who has inspired her this year. She is also said to be caring and a popular member of the class.

Ben also received his report. Which of course was exceptional. Top marks for effort across all subjects. Very similar to Jessica in that he is a pleasure to teach. Anyway without waxing lyrical too much Mummy and Daddy are very pleased and proud.

Ben's SATs results also came back. He didn't do as well as in the mocks so he was a bit disappointed in himself. Also the marks were not super high, the school actually sent a letter out to everyone saying how disappointed they are in the government in that this year have been guinea pigs and hence low scores. Despite that, Ben has come top of the year for maths which is gratifying to know.

In the morning Daddy and Katie kayaked from Elstead to Eashing along the River Wey. It was downstream and the river moved quite quickly in parts. This makes it very difficult to control the vessel. The river was very bendy with plenty of obstacles, be it overhanging trees, trunks laying the river, shallow bit meaning grounding and even a fisherman's line which we almost went into. Lucky he whipped the line away quick!

Daddy paddling

Katie looking where she is going down the Wey!

Daddy had to get into the water a number of times just to make sure his princess was not in danger of getting wet.

They finally reached the pub at Eashing. However, the spur which Daddy had planned to go down had an unknown weir to tackle. To tough with a princess, so back tracking up the river they decided to get out just before the pub onto someone's land. Daddy walked to the house when a neighbour stopped him and grilled him before allowing them to pass through and drop off all the lifejackets, bag, paddles, etc. When they returned to get the kayak a different neighbour came out and mentioned it was private land and the problems they have with trespasses. Again Daddy managed to be subservient enough to get away with it.

In the afternoon Ma ma, Pop Pop and great Grandma came over to watch the Frimley Green Carnival procession. Later Jessica performed with Liberty Gym on the green to the masses. She did very well.

Jessica in her gym display at Frimley Carnival

Later in the afternoon Ben went to Freddie's football birthday party.

title.value: Daddy's 41st Birthday, Frimley Green Carnival, Freddie's birthday party

info.content:
After a slow-ish parkrun, we headed off to Henley for firstly a picnic by the river, then an hours playing on a motorboat. Unknown to us the Henley Festival was on, which I think encompasses the Regatta. Anyway all us children had a go on the steering wheel. It was good fun going up as far as the lock one way, then where the races ended the other.

Picnic by the River in Henley

Motor boating on the Thames at Henley

Today's driver is Jessica

In the evening Daddy went out to the Aviator in Farnborough for Emma's 45th birthday. The hotel was very plush. We got a disturbing insight into Chris's psyche, concerning old body parts!

Ben had a cinema party at Magnus's, Jessica also had a party.

Meanwhile Katie was taken out with the Teales to Southend on Sea.... and again more fairground stuff. Katie had a great time and gets on so well with Summer.

In the morning Daddy and Ben went to parkrun and completed an average run. At lunch Daddy did a BBQ and the Teales joined us for some charcoaled food. The weather was showery mixed in with sunshine as we headed up to Deepcut and the army show. The usual fair, however, the weather got in the way. Still the rope over the water was the highlight. Ben scrambled across quickly and confidently. Jessica went across bravely. You could see that she was a bit scared and was hurting her. The fairground rides was pretty much all the kiddies were after.

Ben doing the rope bridge

Jessica doing the rope bridge

In the evening Mummy went off to the Dartford Taverna for Auntie Charlottes Bacheloress party (Hen Night).

Chardo

The Westons

title.value: RLC Army Show with Teales, Charlotte Hen Night

info.content:
It's not really a marathon. However, the 5.5 mile course has a variety of ground from bogs, sand, tarmac, mud and even a river crossing - yes wet feet. Daddy also had some sunshine and rain. Good fun.

Elstead Marathon
Ben and his friend Olifer auditioned for Frimley CofE Got talent contest. He's written a song which they are performing. They won through to the finals. Well done Ben.

title.value: Ben auditions in Frimley's Got Talent

info.content: Jessica's brownie pack / troop went to Cedar Lodge and sang some Brownie Songs to the old folk.

title.value: Jessica sings at old people's home

info.content:
After church we headed off to Brooklands Community Park for a family picnic with the Weston's, Barnett's and Gay's. Mummy got a load more presents, including one from Steven and Matt which was a trip to see the Bodygaurd at the theatre in London and an Aston Martin experience from Autnie Susan and the Fars and a tent from Ma Ma.

Mummy looking beautiful

Firework on the cake!

Today it was actually Mummy's 40th birthday. We woke in the hotel room and Mummy opened her cards and presents. She got 50 pounds Primark vouchers from Great Grandma, a lovely 'Laura' book from Helen, a neck garment from Fiona, some earrings, a necklace with our names on it from Daddy, a purse from Ben, and a set of pyjamas from Jessica.

Croissants and strawberries for breakfast. Daddy and Ben went off to do the local parkrun. The 26th different parkrun! Ben was blocked off a couple of times when he tried to overtake this older boy. Not very nice. Daddy had to have a word. Anyway they cut through a golf course. Maybe the first 5km lap course.

A quick shower and an argument with a busy body stopping us from waiting in a disabled parking zone later and we were away towards Bourneville and Cadbury's World.

We just about made it for the 11am start, and instantly 15 bars of chocolate were planted in Daddy's lap. Great! There were a number of sections throughout the factory, from the history of cocoa and Cadbury's, to live chocolate making, packaging and advertising. Both us and the 'elderlies' (as Jessica now calls Mummy and Daddy) enjoyed it equally. A picnic later and we queued for the 4D cinema and magic show. A really good day out for £56.

History of chocolate section

Chocolate with choice of toppings! Heaven.

Mirror, mirror on the wall who is the most beautiful of them all

Chocolate electric guitar

Family chocolate shot

Chocolate drops

A long trek home arriving just in time to watch the end of the Wales and Northern Ireland game. The Fars later popped over to give part of their present, a hanging basket. A good day

Daddy took a half day and prepared for the journey up to Leamington Spa. We headed up on to the M40 after school and got to Leamington Spa about 7pm. It was kind of a surprise. Jessica revelled in the fact she knew where we were going, but Mummy didn't. Daddy had looked up this cool pizza restaurant which was a bit different to the usual setting. We sat down in the basement and munched on pizza, chips and mummy even had a cheeky beer. We walked the scenic route back to our hotel which was right in the middle of town, next to the pump rooms. We had a lovely evening just the five of us.

Leamington town

Basement Browns

Bridge over the River Leam

Striding past the pump rooms
For Farfar's Father's Day present Daddy booked a Hogs Back Brewery tour. It was a really good evening spent. Interesting what the tour guide had to say, and nice beer to boot.

We hosted a number of Daddy's friends for the final group game, England v Slovakia. Daddy was on the BBQ tongs. It was good to see a mix of Casuals friends and parkrun friends. The game itself was dire 0-0 draw. But we are through to the next round. Atendees: James and Duncan Ball, Chris Peddle, Woody, Bob, Alasdair, Nick King, Phil Roe, Martin Aves, Michael and Joey Elder.

In the morning we woke and gave Daddy his Father's Day presents. A bottle of alcoholic ginger beer from Katie and a Star Wars t-shirt from Ben. Jessica was away still on Brownie Camp. After croissants in bed, Daddy, Katie and Ben went over to the Fars to wish him happy fathers day. We played a game of Danish Kings in the back garden which was tactical. Katie made a big 'Summer' poster.

Meanwhile Mummy was at church and Daddy left the children to go and collect Jessica from Brownie camp in Elstead. She had a great time.

We all reconvened and headed off to the Pick Your Own place in Addlestone. Eat one strawberry, put one in the punnet. £15 later and we had 3 punnets of sumptuous strawberries.

Strawberry picking

We then trailed over to Reigate Park to meet up with Ma Ma and Pop Pop. We played on the swings and had a late afternoon picnic. All three dads met.

Our fathers

Jessica was sort of looking forward to Brownie Camp. She wanted to be at home for father's day. However, she was looking forward to the Alice In Wonderland themed trip away. She stayed overnight.

Scarecrow fair

In the evening Mummy was taken out by Paula, Lindsey and Sylvie to Zizi's in Camberley for a birthday meal.

The girls

Mummy loves cake

title.value: Jessica on Brownie Camp, Pirbright Scarecrow Fair, Birthday Meal

info.content:
Today Ben left at 5:30am for his school's trip to France. We are all very sad. Ben is very excited.

13th June

We arrived at Le Manoir at around 6pm French time, after a long day travelling. There was lots of entertainment on the ferry to keep the children occupied, including a limbo competition! After settling in, we had a lovely (and very filling) dinner and we are now sat outside shivering and windswept while the children blow off some steam! I'm looking forward to bedtime.....

14 June

Lovely morning exploring the picturesque town of St Malo - the children spoke French very well when buying their delicious ice creams, although some had eyes bigger than their stomachs (deux boules s'il vous plait)! We then had a picnic lunch on the coach as there was a downpour, followed by a fun afternoon in the aquarium! Bit of downtime and diary writing now, with some play time before dinner and much needed tea/coffee for the adults!

St Malo

15 June

Lovely sunny morning for a trip around the bay on an open top boat; picnic lunch back at the centre, followed by a trip to the beach - we are optimists! We got rained on in a heavy shower, but luckily it calmed down and we had a pleasant afternoon! ?? Find the wallies in the photo....

Ben at the front

16 June

Lovely morning shopping at Dinan Market and strolling around the town, followed by an afternoon of outdoor games in beautiful sunshine. A quick trip to the supermarket followed that (sorry, they headed straight for the confectionary aisle!) and we are now packing and having some down time after a lovely traditional dinner from the region.

Daddy started Sunday at 2:05am with a night time run with torch. The night time run was 3 minutes slower than the previous two laps. It was quite nice to run at night, giving a different perspective on the course. So nice and quiet.

The rain woke Daddy up in the tent at about 5:30am. A few others were about. The fourth and final run completed in 47 minutes again and Daddy was done! Great atmosphere between the Flyers. Really nice to have them around. Wouldn't do it otherwise. We had some debutants. We also had Richard and Hannah going around as solo athletes! Unbelievable. We collected our medal, packed the tents away, said our fairwells.

The krew

Parade lap at the end

Team line up

Daddy then had to motorbike over to Leatherhead over an hour away to meet us for the Little Welly event. However, due to the lack of sleep and weekend's exerts he was beginning to fall asleep at the wheel of the motorbike. So decided to turn off at the next junction, Slough and found a grass verge outside the Marriott hotel to have a little kip. Waking 20 minutes later, the motorbike had a flat battery and after calling the breakdown van found out it was a charging fault. So it was bundled into the back of the van, Aldershot bound!

Meanwhile the rest of us met up with Joey for the Little Welly event at Bockett's Farm. It was a 2 mile assault course for children. Ben proudly won. However, the others did not treat it as a race. There were A frames to climb over, cargo nets to crawl under, mud baths to tackle and a foam pool. Over 20 obstacles. It was great fun!

Starting off with the hay bail challenge

The slide after the mud bath

The final foam pit

In the morning Daddy and Ben went to Rushmoor parkrun as Frimley Lodge was shut due to the travellers lurking around in the area. Ben does not like the Rushmoor circuit too much.

Jessica went to a birthday party in the morning.

After the 3 mile, 27 minute jog, Daddy went off to Wasing Park for this years Endure 24. Another two Frimley Flyers teams. Basically the team participates in a relay race around a 5 mile circuit, for 24 hours non-stop, midday Saturday to midday Sunday. On average each team member will complete 4 laps, 20 miles, doing one lap in the dark! The venue itself boasts many tents for massages, food, sports clothing and this year a massive TV screen.... needed for the Euro 16 matches. Daddy was sharing a tent with Alasdair again, who kindly put it up the day before. A star.

We all came over to see Daddy complete his first lap at about 3:30pm. He was being chased by a man with a sword! He completed his first lap in 43 minutes in warm, muggy conditions. After a tour of camp we went back home, leaving Daddy to complete his 2nd lap whilst the England game was on!

Capture the Saturday

The krew

Looking fresh at the start

title.value: parkrun, Jess at party, Endure24 Day 1

info.content:
Today we had fibre installed via Virgin. Hopefully satisfy our growing needs!

Also had motorbike MOT, Katie's sports day and Daddy ill. Katie's team won the event although she did not win her races (300m and 100 metre relay).

Katie in full flow

Sitting in the finishers area

After church we headed over to the other side of Surrey, first collecting Katie who had a sleepover at Summer Teales. They are very good friends. Outwood is 5 miles south of Godstone. The weather was vey warm. We had a picnic as soon as we arrived, then proceeded on a 3 mile walk, mainly through farmers fields it seemed. It was very nice to be just the five of us - us kiddies got on well together.

Picnic

Jessica enjoying chocolate cake

A kiss for the kissing gate

Daddy and big boys

Summer strolling through farmers fields

Old Oak
We went with the girls crew to Thorpe Park, taking Summer with us. Ben is just about 1.4m tall, so could go on all the cool rides which he absolutely loved.

Half term week and we went off to Margate for a 11am kickoff at Dreamland, which used to be the Benborn Brothers Amusement Park. We met with the Borrows and Morleys. Daddy came along for the ride as he thought it was different to the normal theme parks. Mummy and Daddy went there once before they were married.

For June it was flipping freezing. It felt like October. No matter, the rain just about held off which was the most important thing and the weather actually probably worked in our favour as it might have kept more people from coming. The kiddies were determined to go on everything they could... and they pretty much did. Quite a few of the amusements were shut, either because of maitenance or staff shortages. The rollercoaster was not running because of the wood expanding in the damp conditions!Still we had a good time on what was open. One of the favourites was the Spinning 'Barrel of laughs' ride.

In Dreamland

We headed inside for a bit and went on the Roller Disco, some showing better moves than others. Mummy thought she was the bees knees.

Natasha, Daddy and Katie on the Big Wheel

Girls Roller Discoing

The Two Spins was the adults favourite, whilst most of the thrill seeker children liked the Barrel of Laughs ride the most. On the way home we stopped off for Sausage and Chips. Summer came over for a sleepover which made Katie very happy.

After church, we embarked on day 2 of our Basingstoke Canal journey, this time the enthusiasm was quite low amongst the younger generation. A raise of the saddle and Jessica was zooming and no problem with her happiness levels. Every person she passed were greeted with a 'hello, thank you and goodbye' in a Jessica, jolly voice. As Daddy was behind, he managed to capture the laughter reaction!

Katie at Deepcut lock

Daddy's favourite part of canal is probably the stretch between Deepcut and St John's. Some picture postcard scenes especially with the sun beating down on to the trees and canal. A lovely sight. Then trouble struck. A Canadian Goose and his young family sat in the path and were not intending to move. He actually ran 10 metres down the canal chasing Daddy, who was as brave as a 'no very brave' person and backed right off. So we had to go back to the last bridge and go on to the other side of the canal!

Ben scooting on down

We stopped at St Johns for a picnic beside the canal, before continuing on again to Goldsworth Park and an expensive Beefeater, where we stopped for Coke and chips! On the other side of Woking we stopped again at the playground and bike halfpipe.

Woking playground

Ben was not feeling too well, so we scotted along to the end at Byfleet and by far the ugliest view of the whole trip. The M25 motorway, a nasty looking bridge and scrubland! Still we made it. well done all.

The end at Byfleet

We cycled onto Byfleet and New Haw station and caught a train back to Farnborough Main and rode home and collapsed in front of the TV!

Ben and Daddy parkrunned, without initially putting any efforts towards a Ben pb. However, after 3km Ben streaked away and came in with a new 23:57 pb - 40 seconds ahead of Daddy! Well done Ben.

Ben's Rio moment

As a family we decided we were going to cycle the length of the Basingstoke Canal over 2 days. Fortunately we live near the middle of the canal so day 1 was heading west towards Basingstoke. Enthusiasm was buoyed by the promise of pub stops and ice creams. First stop was the Mytchett Canal centre where we met with the parkrun crew and our first set of ice creams.

Next stop was the Swan in Ash Vale. At this rate Daddy was going to be bankrupt and it'll take till midnight to reach our destination! Fortunately we picked up a bit of momentum and reached our picnic destination in Pyestock before moving on. Bottoms were getting sore, but us children got on. Jessica did especially well considering the bike she has and the lack of gear changing. One more pub stop at the Fox and Hounds, Church Crookham before making the long picturesque ride to Odiham. We stopped off at an old pill box. Only some were brave enough to enter. The castle never to seem to come. Eventually we stopped off where Daddy spilt water all over his trousers. It look liked he wet himself! Greywell tunnel was reached finally. A sense of relief and achievement when we got there.

Mumma and Daddy

Katie at bridge

The crew towpathing it down the canal

Odiham Castle. Jessica's roll can be seen!

Greywell Tunnel

We had a couple of miles cycle on to Hook railway station. We bought in supplies and had a BBQ when we got home! We were all ready for Britain's Got Talent and Champions League finals.

title.value: Ben parkrun PB, Basingstoke Canal Ride (West)

info.content:
We had one last go in the swimming pool before a frantic clean-up, bacon and egg baps for breakfast and of course the farewell photo.

The Weston's

We end our weekend by going to Avon Heath Country Park, where we played on the playground, went for a walk and had a picnic. Daddy had decided to bike from the house and took ages. He tried to take a risky shortcut, climbed over fences with a bike, crossed the busy A338 (cars beeping) and got lost! He eventually found us!

The trip ended fittingly with a burst of rain, everyone ran for cover into their cars and sailed off home.

Later in the afternoon we went around to the Fars and played Coppitt.

title.value: Shobley Retreat - Day 3 - Avon Heath Country Park, Fars

info.content:
The weather wasn't great today, however, that did not deter at least the adults from venturing out. First up was the Moors Valley parkrun which was unusual in that it was a single 5km loop in the country park.

Moors Valley parkrunners

Daddy and Michael took Lennie for a walk out in the rain and the New Forest. It was a lovely ride, not seeing another sole for an hour or so. Lennie loved it.

New Forest Bike Ride with Lennie and Michael

Later all the adults went for a walk. The children surprisingly didn't want to. They just wanted to live in the swimming pool.

Mummy and Daddy walking in the rain

Later in the afternoon we watched the FA Cup final and Britain's Got Talent and some of us got into bed with Ma Ma and Pop Pop and played some funny games.

7 in a bed, roll over, roll over

We decided as it was Charlotte's 30th and Mummy's 40th that we all go and spend a family weekend away in a big house on the edge of the New Forest. So a million pound house was selected with an indoor swimming pool. The children mostly played in the swimming pool with the odd game of football chucked in.

Living in the swimming pool

Happy eaters

In the morning we went off to church. Mummy was leader today for the 4 to 7 year olds, which meant we all got out of church as well.

Meanwhile Daddy had arranged a Rockets ride for the Mallorca crew around the Dilley Lane loop. Lovely ride ending in Hartley Whitney for a coffee.

The Rockets

In the afternoon we had Theo's birthday party which we were contemplating boycotting due to some of the issues we have with Theo. More out of pity for the parents we allowed Ben to go to the Kayaking party at the Kingfisher lake. The rest of us, plus Natasha biked down shortly afterwards and enjoyed mucking about in the sun.

In the morning we were set for Ben getting a PB after the cock up at Winchester last week. It was almost expected he was going to break 24:52. James joined us on the run, and we were in a 'PB train'. Woo Hoo. First km, was 5:04.... outside the pace, however, we had negative splits all the way to the finish, ending on a 4:27 final km. Finish time was 23:59, taking a massive chunk out of the pb. Well done Ben

We of course went to the café afterwards and drank the well earnt Rio!

Rio jump shot! Woo Hoo.

Ben chatting with the other Flyers

We didn't have long until we had to get ready for Pip and Stephen's wedding in Farnham. Pip is a friend we've known since Ben's Pre School days. Ben and Jasper are friends as well as Mummy and Pip often meeting up now in holidays since Pip has moved to Wrecclesham. We also see each other at parkrun occasionally.

The wedding itself was at St Andrews in Farnham.

Ceremony over, march out of church

Family Shot

Katie and Daddy

After the ceremony was slunk off back home for a bit before returning for the evening do where Mummy was enjoying her dancing!

Mumma and a Dadda

Disco Dancers

title.value: Ben parkrun PB - Pip and Stephen Wedding

info.content:
Mummy - How hard can it be, a parkrun with 5 rests in between?

The Windlesham Pairs event was held at the memorial field where there were 123 pairs who alternately run a 1km loop. 5km in total for each person. There were fears how seriously this was taken and whether Mummy and Daddy would come last. Mummy lead out the first leg at a quick pace, but blew up after about 200 metres and found the other 800 metres tough! The baton handed over to Daddy who set off. The course deceptively was all up hill! Anyway Daddy completed his 5x1km's all within 6 seconds of each other, 4:45/km-ish.

Mummy did ever so well considering she blew up so early. Good determination. They finished 93rd out of 123, which was respectable, seeing Mummy has done relatively zero training.

Mumma sporting her sporty look

Team GAY

The Flyers group shot

This week Ben is doing his SATS. We are all fairly relaxed and chilled about it. Ben has been additional practice papers at home. At school he came top of the year for maths achieving 159 out of 160. The one he got wrong was genuine not knowing the answer, rather than making a mistake. Good luck Ben.

The girls stayed up late again last night playing Sims 3, despite having Sims 4! In the morning Daddy fixed up Ben's bike once and for all, learning how to adjust the brake blocks finally.

Because there was not enough room in the car, Daddy cycled over to Guildford where we went swimming at the Spectrum. I say swimming. Ben spent much of the time on the 5 metre diving board. Katie and Summer went off together and Jessica was doing forward somersaults off the 1 metre board, much to Daddy's delight, as well as jumping off the 3 metre board. She did try 5 metres, but peering down she lost her nerve and came back again. After, we returned Summer back to her mum, came home and relaxed.

Summer is stayed over this weekend. Jessica went over to the Teale household last night for a sleepover also. We got up early in the morning and all headed down to Winchester for the parkrun. Katie and Summer decided to join in, however they walked and posed a lot! Ben and Daddy went around the 3 lap course at a good pace. Come the 4km marker, Ben left Daddy for dust and gained a 30 seconds lead or so. Ben was set to smash his pb. However, when it came to the last 200 metres he went the wrong direction and hadn't noticed the detour to the finish line. In the end Ben finished 2 seconds outside his pb, despite running for an additional 30 seconds minimum. Ben was gutted and was reduced to tears given the amount of effort he had put in. Next week Ben.

We continued down to Bournemouth. The weather was top notch. Really summer, low 20's centigrade. The girls demanded a shopping spree, so they were given some money and 2 hours to wander around the shops. Boots and Primark seemed the longest stops. Meanwhile, Mummy, Daddy and Ben parked the car up out of town (Cavendish Road) and took a nice walk in, visited some surf and sports shops and had a milkshake from Shakeaway. A very nice relaxing time.

In the afternoon we went to Charlotte's house where Loz was cooking up a nice BBQ for us and family. We got our Jessica back again as Ma Ma and Pop Pop brought her over from the Teale's.

We went over to the park for a bit of a play, after which we played Piñata... which had no sweets in the middle. Loz's Dad's Dog, Lenny was there and it's the first time both Katie, Mummy and Jessica have all warmed to a dog. He was so placid and well behaved.

Jessica with Lenny

Mummy and Jessica went home with Ma Ma and Pop Pop, whilst the rest of us went down to Boscombe beach for a bit. We played in the sea, did a bit of sunbathing, pier walking and rock climbing. We ended the day with some fish and chips.

Katie and Summer entering Boscombe Beach

Playing in the sea

Ben on the rock

Cruising down the beach

Here is the result of our blogging from today's shopping trip...
